title: 107_hr930
content: The "Social Security Right To Know Act" requires specific material to be included in the annual report of trustees. Section 201(c) of the Social Security Act is amended to redesignate paragraphs, insert new subparagraphs, and rearrange sentences within the paragraphs. Section 201(c) of the Social Security Act is amended to redesignate paragraphs and rearrange sentences within the paragraphs. This includes changes such as inserting new subparagraphs and striking certain sentences to modify the structure of the section. The Social Security Act is amended to redesignate paragraphs and rearrange sentences, including inserting new subparagraphs and providing statements on the unfunded long-term liability of the social security system. The Social Security Act is amended to include reporting requirements on the financial projections of the social security system, including deficit/surplus amounts and economic models used. The Trust Funds balances are explained as resources authorized by Congress for future benefits. The Trust Funds balances are claims against the United States Treasury that must be financed through increased taxes, public borrowing, benefit reduction, or elimination of other Federal expenditures. SEC. 3. MATERIAL TO BE INCLUDED IN SOCIAL SECURITY ACCOUNT STATEMENT. Section 1143(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include a comparison of annual social security tax inflows to benefits paid annually, determined by the Chief Actuary of the Social Security Administration. The amended Section 1143(a) of the Social Security Act requires an explanation of cash flow deficits, when they will start, when trust fund funds will no longer cover deficits, and the percentage of benefits that can be paid from social security tax inflows. It also mandates an explanation of the average rate of return on old-age insurance benefits compared to total social security taxes paid. The amended Section 1143(a) of the Social Security Act requires an explanation of cash flow deficits, trust fund coverage, and benefits paid from tax inflows. It also mandates details on the average rate of return on old-age insurance benefits compared to total social security taxes paid. The total amount of social security taxes paid by taxpayers, including inflation-adjusted rates of return for workers born from 1900 onwards, is presented in a chart or graph with an explanatory caption by the Chief Actuary of the Social Security Administration. SEC. 4. USE OF CONTINUOUS WORK HISTORY SAMPLE FOR STATISTICAL RESEARCH. The Social Security Administration will provide the Continuous Work History Sample (CWHS) data for statistical research purposes, with limitations on data release to ensure individual privacy. The Continuous Work History Sample (CWHS) data from the Social Security Administration is provided for statistical research purposes, with privacy protections in place. Personally Identifiable Information is removed before data release, and users must reimburse the Office of Research and Statistics for the data. Definitions include CWHS as the sample of administrative records and a user as anyone accessing the CWHS.
